title: 109_s1881
content:
The Act is titled the "San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The San Francisco Old Mint, known as the Granite Lady, was crucial in the nation's history. Established in 1852 to convert gold into coins, it was designed by architect A.B. Mullett. The building survived the 1906 earthquake and fire, serving as the treasury for disaster relief funds. Coins from the mint are marked with an "S". The San Francisco Old Mint, with the "S" mint mark, struck rare coins like the 1870-S $3 coin worth over $1,000,000 and the 1894-S dime. The San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin will be the first to honor a US mint facility. The San Francisco Old Mint, with the "S" mint mark, struck rare coins like the 1870-S $3 coin worth over $1,000,000 and the 1894-S dime. The San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin will be the first to honor a US mint facility. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the San Francisco Old Mint. The $5 coins will weigh 8.359 grams and contain 90% gold, while the $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams and contain 90% silver. These coins will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items for legal tender purposes. The design of coins is specified under SEC. 4. Design requirements for coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of the San Francisco Old Mint Building, its importance to California and US history, and its role in rebuilding San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake and fire. Each coin must have a value designation, the year "2006" inscribed, and include words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Board of the San Francisco. The design for coins minted under this Act must be emblematic of the San Francisco Old Mint Building and its historical significance. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts, the Board of the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the San Francisco Mint. The Secretary may only issue these coins during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2006.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount. SEC. 7 of the Act specifies surcharges for coins minted under the Act, including $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society for the rehabilitation of the Historic Old Mint in San Francisco. The Society will be audited for the amounts received.
